channel.title: RSS Feed from LA Daily News: http://sstapleton-development.mn1.dc.publicus.com
channel.description: The latest news from LA Daily News: http://sstapleton-development.mn1.dc.publicus.com website: all stories : extended version

item.title: Labor force in a tough spot on its special day: Editorial
item.description:
You don't have to look far for to find a reason to celebrate this Labor Day ­- barbecues, pool parties, shopping - but there's one reason not to. The actual state of labor, while improving, is still grim.

The unemployment rate in Los Angeles County hovers near 10 percent and that doesn't even account for the thousands that have completely dropped out of the workforce.

media:content.media:description: Fast-food worker Michelle Osborn, 23, of Flint shouts out chants as she and a few dozen others strike outside of McDonald's on Wednesday, July 31, 2013 in Flint. (AP Photo/The Flint Journal, Jake May)

item.title: Surf's up at Great Sand Dunes National Park
item.description:
Surf's up dude! Grab your board for the ride of your life at Great Sand Dunes National Park in Colorado.

Josh came up from Denver on his birthday to sand board the Big Kahuna. A 750-foot-high sand monster called Star Dune. Kelsey was busy waxing her sand sled while a friend stood by with the sand board he had rented from a nearby store.
item.dc:creator: Richard Irwin, San Gabriel Valley Tribune

item.title: Hundreds celebrate labor movement in Wilmington
item.description:
WILMINGTON >> Members of more than three dozen unions gathered on the day dedicated to labor and called for more fully funded education, protection of collective bargaining rights, better health care and immigration reform.

"There are 11 million people who don't have the same rights on the job.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Wong grace.wong@presstelegram.com

item.title: Richards helps Angels pound Rays 11-2
item.description:
ANAHEIM>> Garrett Richards worked around a career-high seven walks over five innings and Erick Aybar drove in four runs, helping the Angels beat the Tampa Bay Rays 11-2 on Monday night at Angel Stadium.

Richards (5-6) gave up a run and two hits while striking out six in the opener of a four-game series.
item.dc:creator: By Joe Resnick The Associated Press

item.title: UCLA safety Goforth developing leadership skills
item.description:
Randall Goforth stood outside the UCLA football locker room at the Rose Bowl late Saturday night, pleased but hardly satisfied.

The Bruins had just completed a 58-20 thrashing of Nevada in a season opener that can be best described as dominant.

It was an impressive victory that left many re-evaluating their beliefs about UCLA and wondering just how high the Bruins can climb in year two under head coach Jim Mora.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Bonsignore, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: UCLA sophomore safety Randall Goforth is “a cool customer,” Bruins coach Jim Mora says.
Randall Goforth is emerging as the Bruins’ defensive leader, UCLA defensive backs coach Demetrice Martin said.

item.title: USC QB Cody Kessler to start against Washington State
item.description:
USC's quarterback rotation against Washington State on Saturday will look similar to last week, with Cody Kessler starting and Max Wittek coming on in relief, although Trojans coach Lane Kiffin still will not actually divulge his plans.

Kiffin said Sunday he told his plans to Kessler and Wittek and sources said he told the quarterbacks he would follow the same plan as in the opener against Hawaii.
item.dc:creator: Scott Wolf, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: USC quarterback Cody Kessler looks to pass during a practice at the Howard Jones Field at USC Monday August 19, 2013. Kessler will start against Washington State on Saturday. Hawaii. (Andy Holzman/Los Angeles Daily News)

item.title: Kershaw hit hard, Dodgers top Rockies; Puig hurt
item.description:
DENVER >> Clayton Kershaw turned in a clunker, a rare bad outing for one of baseball's best pitchers.

After the game, Dodgers manager Don Mattingly was asked a question he hardly ever hears: What's wrong with Kershaw?

"Who got the win today?" Mattingly teased.
item.dc:creator: By Pat Graham The Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Dodgers right fielder Yasiel Puig looks on against the Colorado Rockies in the fifth inning of a baseball game in Denver on Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. (AP Photo/David Zalubowski)

item.title: CHATTER: Harvard-Westlake's Jack Flaherty can't lift U.S. 18-under national baseball team to another World Cup win
item.description:
After Jack Flaherty got the U.S. 18-under national baseball team off to a strong start Sunday at the IBAF World Cup, the Americans couldn't deliver a similar performance Monday against Australia in Taichung, Taiwan.

The U.S. collected five hits against three Australian pitchers and suffered a 1-0 pool-play loss, putting early pressure on the defending champions in the Americans' pursuit to repeat.

item.title: San Pedro's Conquer the Bridge run/walk is a labor of love
item.description:
For the nearly 3,000 people who took part in Monday's Conquer the Bridge run/walk, Labor Day contained a fair amount of labor.

"They work so hard to do this race," said Michael-Patrick Hogue, race founder and organizer. "This is not an easy race."

No kidding.
item.dc:creator: Donna Littlejohn, LA Daily News

media:content.media:description: Conquer the Bridge Labor Day run in San Pedro. Heading to the top of the Vincent Thomas Bridge. Photo by Brad Graverson 9-2-13
Conquer the Bridge Labor Day run in San Pedro. Start of the 5.3 mile bridge run. Photo by Brad Graverson 9-2-13

item.title: Sober living house operators say Pasadena wants them out
item.description:
PASADENA>> When Robert Holbrook turned 22, he realized he needed to turn his life around.

Struggling with alcohol addiction from a young age, Holbrook enrolled in the Gooden Center sober living facility in Pasadena in 1989.

Fifteen years later, he decided to give back and founded the Recovery Alliance Foundation, and ultimately opened 29 sober living houses in the San Gabriel and San Fernando Valleys, including 12 in Pasadena.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Gold, Pasadena Star-News

item.title: Time Warner, CBS reach Labor Day deal
item.description: One day before the Los Angeles City Council vowed to begin to aggressively address the issue of Time Warner Cable blacking out two local CBS channels, the two battling media companies reached a carriage agreement Monday afternoon restoring the service to more than one million Southern California customers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Hoffarth, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:title: Did you cancel your TW sub?

media:content.media:description: "Survivor: Blood vs. Water" premieres Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2013, with a 90-minute episode on CBS.

item.title: How will L.A.'s top officials be celebrating the Jewish New Year?
item.description:
Los Angeles City Hall is expected to have fewer leaders on deck this week.

With the Jewish New Year beginning at sundown Wednesday, and because several of the city's top elected executives are Jewish, some key offices will be temporarily empty.

New City Controller Ron Galperin, who will take off Thursday and Friday for the holiday, will be celebrating Rosh Hashana with his husband, Rabbi Zach Shapiro, as well as with his own mother and father, a retired rabbi and Holocaust survivor.
item.dc:creator: Brenda Gazzar, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, left, L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin, middle, and L.A. City Attorney Mike Feuer meet at Brent's Deli in Northridge in July after taking office. (Courtesy photo)
L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin chants at a past High Holiday service at Temple Akiba in Culver City. (Photo by Brad Herman)
L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin, left, with his husband Rabbi Zach Shapiro at the mayor’s gay pride garden party in June.
L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin, left, with husband Rabbi Zach Shapiro at his inauguration in June.
L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin, left, with husband Rabbi Zach Shapiro at a fundraiser held in February for his recent election bid.

item.title: A call to crack down on those who pay for child sex
item.description:
Saying not enough has been done to crack down on people who exploit children forced to become prostitutes, Los Angeles county officials will launch a campaign Tuesday to make California the most expensive state in the country to be convicted of soliciting sex from a minor.

Supervisors Don Knabe and Mark Ridley-Thomas are set to introduce a motion asking the state legislature to stiffen penalties for so-called "johns" from $1,000 to $10,000.
item.dc:creator: Christina Villacorte, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: Obama tries persuading the skeptical on Syria
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama got some conditional support for military intervention in Syria from two key Republican foreign policy hawks Monday who said the president still needs to make a strong case for attacking the regime of President Bashar Assad if he wants to win congressional backing.
item.dc:creator: Jim Kuhnhenn Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., left, accompanied by Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., speaks with reporters outside the White House in Washington, Monday, Sept. 2, 2013, following a closed-door meeting with President Barack Obama to discuss the situation with Syria. President Barack Obama, working to persuade skeptical lawmakers to endorse a U.S. military intervention in civil war-wracked Syria, hosted the two leading Capitol Hill foreign policy hawks for talks and directed his national security team to testify before Congress in a determined effort to sell his plan for limited missile strikes against Syrian President Bashar Assad's regime. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)

item.title: Dense smoke blocks views, brings health warning in Yosemite Valley
item.description:
YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK - Favorable weather is helping crews make advances against a wildfire burning in and around Yosemite National Park, a wild land blaze that has expanded to become the fourth-largest in modern California history,

Clouds and higher humidity slowed flames from advancing through brush and trees, giving firefighters room to set backfires, dig containment lines and to strengthen lines around threatened communities, fire spokesman Trevor Augustino said.
item.dc:creator: By Gosia Wozniacka Associated Press

media:content.media:description: In this Friday, Aug. 30, 2013 photo provided by the U.S. Forest Service, firefighters, right, watch over a burn operation on the southern flank of the Rim Fire near Yosemite National Park in California. The wildfire burning in and around Yosemite National Park has become the fourth-largest conflagration in California history. (AP Photo/U.S. Forest Service, Mike McMillan)

item.title: Man suffers serious burns when his car crashes in Granada Hills
item.description:
A man remained hospitalized Monday morning with serious burns after he was trapped for a time inside his burning car following a crash in Granada Hills, a Los Angeles police sergeant said.

The crash took place shortly before midnight Sunday in the 13900 blocl of Balboa Blvd., , said LAPD Sgt.
item.dc:creator: By City News Service

item.title: Three shot, two stabbed in Hollywood
item.description:
A woman and two men were shot, and two men were stabbed in two separate unrelated incidences that occurred around the same time early Sunday morning in Hollywood, according to the Los Angeles Police Department.

Police said the woman and two men were shot outside a club at Ivar Avenue and Yucca Street in Hollywood after an argument erupted with three other men, said LAPD Officer Rosario Herrera.
item.dc:creator: Susan Abram, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: Hollywood's summer box office was boffo, despite big flops
item.description:
The biggest Labor Day moviegoing weekend of all time, estimated at $150 million, capped a record box office summer.

And we do mean record.

With an estimated domestic gross of more than $4.7 billion from the first weekend of May through Labor Day, the film industry is a whopping 10.23 percent ahead of what was earned during the same period in 2012.
item.dc:creator: Bob Strauss, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Iron Man and Gwyneth Paltrow stars as Pepper Potts in Walt Disney Pictures' Iron Man 3 (2013)
Jerry the Minion and Stuart the Minion from Universal Pictures' Despicable Me 2 (2013)

item.title: Germany tries 92-year-old for Nazi war crime
item.description:
HAGEN, Germany (AP) - Germany put a 92-year-old former member of the Nazi Waffen SS on trial Monday on charges that he killed a Dutch resistance fighter in 1944.

Dutch-born Siert Bruins, who is now German, entered the Hagen state courtroom using a walker, but appeared alert and attentive as the proceedings opened.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL NIEMANN Daniel Niemann Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Siert Bruins , 92-year-old former member of the Nazi Waffen SS, right, and his lawyer Klaus-Peter Kniffke, second right, stand in the courtroom of the court in Hagen, Germany, Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. Dutch-born Siert Bruins, who is now a German, is on trial on allegations he executed a Dutch resistance fighter in 1944. (AP Photo/Frank Augstein)

Siert Bruins , 92-year-old former member of the Nazi Waffen SS, stands in the courtroom in Hagen, Germany, Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. Dutch-born Siert Bruins, who is now a German, is on trial on allegations he executed a Dutch resistance fighter in 1944. Bruins, who volunteered for the SS after the Nazis took the Netherlands in 1941, already served time in Germany in the 1980s after being found guilty in the wartime killing of two Dutch Jews. (AP Photo/Frank Augstein)

item.title: Sandy's 'freaky' path may be less likely in future
item.description:
WASHINGTON (AP) - Man-made global warming may further lessen the likelihood of the freak atmospheric steering currents that last year shoved Superstorm Sandy due west into New Jersey, a new study says.

But don't celebrate a rare beneficial climate change prediction just yet. The study's authors said the once-in-700-years path was only one factor in the massive $50 billion killer storm.
item.dc:creator: Seth Borenstein AP Science Writer

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Nov. 9, 2012 aerial-file photo, people stand near damaged homes along the Atlantic Ocean in New Jersey after the region was pounded by Superstorm Sandy. Man-made global warming may decrease the likelihood of the already unusual steering currents that pushed Superstorm Sandy due west into New Jersey in a freak 1-in-700 year path, researchers report. While that may sound like the rare good climate change news, it's probably not, according to the study's authors, because they only looked at steering currents and other factors, including stronger storms, and sea level rise can and likely will outweigh any benefit from changing air patterns. The study is disputed by other scientists who have been vocal about the meteorological factors behind Sandy. (AP Photo/Mel Evans, File)

FILE - This Feb. 22,2013 file photo shows Two heavily damaged homes on the beach in Mantoloking, N.J., from Superstorm Sandy. Man-made global warming may decrease the likelihood of the already unusual steering currents that pushed Superstorm Sandy due west into New Jersey in a freak 1-in-700 year path, researchers report. While that may sound like the rare good climate change news, it's probably not, according to the study's authors, because they only looked at steering currents and other factors, including stronger storms, and sea level rise can and likely will outweigh any benefit from changing air patterns. The study is disputed by other scientists who have been vocal about the meteorological factors behind Sandy. (AP Photo/Mel Evans, File)

item.title: Nyad 1st to swim to Florida from Cuba without cage
item.description:
KEY WEST, Fla. (AP) - Looking dazed and sunburned, U.S. endurance swimmer Diana Nyad walked on to the shore Monday, becoming the first person to swim from Cuba to Florida without the help of a shark cage.

The 64-year-old Nyad swam up to the beach just before 2 p.m. EDT, about 53 hours after she began her journey in Havana on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER KAY Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Endurance swimmer Diana Nyad, right, and her trainer, Bonnie Stoll hug after Nyad walks ashore Monday, Sept. 2, 2013 in Key West, Fla. after swimming from Cuba. Nyad became the first person to swim from Cuba to Florida without the help of a shark cage. She arrived at the beach just before 2 p.m. EDT, about 53 hours after she began her swim in Havana on Saturday. (AP Photo/J Pat Carter)

Long distance swimmer Diana Nyad swims towards shore in Key West, Fla., Monday, Sept. 2, 2013, after swimming from Cuba. Nyad became the first person to swim from Cuba to Florida without the help of a shark cage. She arrived at the beach just before 2 p.m. EDT, about 53 hours after she began her swim in Havana on Saturday. (AP Photo/J Pat Carter)

item.title: Long Beach student directs film about Spielberg's return to CSULB
item.description:
LONG BEACH >> NYU. USC. UCLA.

For years, aspiring filmmakers have fought for admission to these schools. But Steven Spielberg, one of the most revered directors in Hollywood, didn't make like Scorcese or Stone and end up at NYU.

Instead he went to Cal State Long Beach in 1965 only to drop out after three years.

media:content.media:description: Actor Robert Laur (center) and Director Joshua Hoh (right) prepare for a scene in "Steven Spielberg and the Return to Film School."

item.title: m,Craft brewers find it's best to do business outside of L.A.
item.description:
Ten weeks after Tom Dunbabin and his business partner walked into Redondo Beach City Hall to discuss opening the community's first craft brewery, they received the unanimous blessing of the Planning Commission.

Construction began almost immediately at their brewery location. Coastline Brewing Co.
item.dc:creator: Nick Green, Daily Breeze

media:content.media:description: Smog City Brewery, Torrance’s newest brewery, is owned by brewmaster Porter and his wife Laurie Porter. Stephen Carr/ Los Angeles Newspaper Group

item.title: French intel: Syrian regime led chemical attack
item.description:
PARIS (AP) - A French intelligence report on Monday alleged that the Syrian regime launched an attack on Aug. 21 that involved a "massive use of chemical agents" and could carry out similar strikes in the future.

The government, on its Web site, published a 9-page intelligence synopsis about Syria's chemical weapons program that found that at least 281 deaths could be attributed to the attack in rebel-held areas outside Damascus.
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Corbert Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Director M. Blash, left, and actress Jena Malone pose during a photo call for their film "The Wait", Monday, Sept. 2, 2013, at the 39th American Film Festival in Deauville, Normandy, western France. (AP Photo/Lionel Cironneau)

item.title: 'Fifty Shades' movie casts Dakota Johnson, Hunnam
item.description:
NEW YORK (AP) - The big-screen adaptation of E L James' "Fifty Shades of Grey" has cast its lead roles.

Charlie Hunnam will play the 27-year-old billionaire Christian Grey, and Dakota Johnson will play the college student he captivates, Anastasia Steele. Focus Features and Universal Pictures announced the castings Monday.
item.dc:creator: Associated Press

media:content.media:description: FILE - Dakota Johnson attends the FOX network upfront presentation party at Wollman Rink, in New York in a May 14, 2012 file photo. Focus Features and Universal Pictures announced Monday, Sept. 2, 2013 that Dakota Johnson will play Anastasia Steele in the big-screen adaptation of E L Jamesí ìFifty Shades of Grey.î Johnson is the daughter of actors Don Johnson and Melanie Griffith. (AP Photo/Evan Agostini, File)

FILE - In a Tuesday, Aug. 30, 2011 file photo, Charlie Hunnam, a cast member in "Sons of Anarchy," arrives at a screening of the fourth season premiere of the television series, in Los Angeles. Focus Features and Universal Pictures announced Monday, Sept. 2, 2013 that Hunnam will play the 27-year-old billionaire Christian Grey in the big-screen adaptation of E L Jamesí ìFifty Shades of Greyî. Dakota Johnson will play the college student he captivates, Anastasia Steele. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello, File)

item.title: Crews make overnight gains on Yosemite wildfire
item.description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. (AP) - Crews working to corral the massive wildfire searing the edge of Yosemite National Park made major gains on the blaze overnight and were anticipating additional advances on Monday with the help of cooler temperatures and higher humidity, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Associated Press

media:content.media:description: In this Friday, Aug. 30, 2013 photo provided by the U.S. Forest Service, a fire crew stands watch along a fire break near a burn operation on the southern flank of the Rim Fire near Yosemite National Park in California. The wildfire burning in and around Yosemite National Park has become the fourth-largest conflagration in California history. (AP Photo/U.S. Forest Service, Mike McMillan)

In this Friday, Aug. 30, 2013 photo provided by the U.S. Forest Service, a member of the Bureau of Land Management Silver State Hotshot crew from Elko, Nevada, stands by a burn operation on the southern flank of the Rim Fire near Yosemite National Park in California. The wildfire burning in and around Yosemite National Park has become the fourth-largest conflagration in California history. (AP Photo/U.S. Forest Service, Mike McMillan)

item.title: Russia may send lawmakers to US to discuss Syria
item.description:
MOSCOW (AP) - President Vladimir Putin hopes to send a delegation of Russian lawmakers to the United States to discuss the situation in Syria with members of Congress, the Interfax news agency reported Monday.

Russian legislators Valentina Matvienko and Sergei Naryshkin proposed that to Putin, saying polls have shown little support among Americans for armed intervention in Syria to punish its regime for an alleged chemical weapons attack.
item.dc:creator: Laura Mills Associated Press

media:content.media:description: A Russian member of a pro-Kremlin party takes part in a picket against a possible US military action against Syria outside the US Consulate in St.Petersburg, Russia, Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. (AP Photo/Dmitry Lovetsky)

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov speaks in Moscow on Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. Russia's foreign minister says the information the U.S. has showed Moscow in trying to prove that the Syrian regime used chemical weapons on its civilians is "absolutely unconvincing." Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov says Washington did not show Russia detailed evidence, such as geographic coordinates or names. (AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko)

item.title: Police: Some leads in fatal shooting of NYC boy, 1
item.description:
NEW YORK (AP) - New York City's police commissioner says investigators have some leads in the killing of a 1-year-old boy who was shot in his stroller while on a walk with his parents.

Commissioner Raymond Kelly and Mayor Michael Bloomberg spoke Monday about the death of Antiq Hennis, who was shot Sunday evening on a Brooklyn street.
item.dc:creator: Associated Press

item.title: Sweden won't raise online spying when Obama visits
item.description:
STOCKHOLM (AP) - Internet freedom activists plan to protest U.S. online spying when Barack Obama visits Stockholm this week, but the Swedish officials say they won't raise the sensitive issue with the U.S. president.

Foreign Minister Carl Bildt told The Associated Press on Monday that government surveillance of the Internet is "going on worldwide" and is not something on the agenda during Obama's visit Wednesday and Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Karl Ritter Associated Press

media:content.media:description: FILE - A Monday, June 24, 2013 photo from files showing Swedish Foreign Minister Carl Bildt, as he talks with journalists on his arrival at a European foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg. Left-wing and Internet freedom activists are likely to protest against U.S. online spying when Barack Obama visits Stockholm this week, but Swedish government officials say they won't raise the sensitive issue with the U.S. president. Foreign Minister Carl Bildt told The Associated Press on Monday, Sept. 2, 2013, that Internet surveillance activities are happening worldwide and that "we are not entirely innocent ourselves. We conduct both intelligence and security operations on the Net. But they are regulated by law." Bildt also noted that the European Union already is in discussions about "data privacy" with the United States.(AP Photo/Geert Vanden Wijngaert, File)

item.title: Heavyweight boxer Tommy Morrison dies at 44
item.description:
Tommy Morrison, the former heavyweight champion who stood toe-to-toe with Lennox Lewis and George Foreman and later tested positive for HIV, died Monday. He was 44.

Morrison died Sunday night at a Nebraska hospital, said Tony Holden, his longtime promoter and close friend. The family would not disclose the cause of death.
item.dc:creator: Dave Skretta AP Sports Writer

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 7, 1993 file photo, newly crowned WBO heavyweight champion Tommy Morrison receives his championship belt after defeating George Foreman in Las Vegas, Nev. Morrison, a former heavyweight champion who gained fame for his role in the movie "Rocky V," has died. He was 44. Morrison's former manager, Tony Holden says his longtime friend died Sunday night, Sept. 1, 2013, at a Nebraska hospital. (AP Photo/Nick Ut, File)

In this Feb. 20, 2007 photo provided by Mountaineer Race Track and Gaming Center, Tommy Morrison is shown in Chester W.Va. Morrison, a former heavyweight champion who gained fame for his role in the movie “Rocky V,” has died. He was 44. Morrison’s former manager, Tony Holden says his longtime friend died Sunday night, Sept. 1, 2013, at a Nebraska hospital. (AP photo/Mountaineer Race Track and Gaming Center, Charles Saus)

item.title: Customs cracks down on counterfeit Cialis, Viagra coming into L.A.
item.description: In a warehouse several miles south of Los Angeles International Airport, a federal officer sits beside an X-ray machine, the belt moving at least three times faster than the typical airport security scanner. Headphones covering her ears, she watches a small monitor as packages - often three or four across - dart across the screen.
item.dc:creator: Brian Sumers, Daily Breeze

media:content.media:description: L CBP officer Cardiff Siu inspects a package that contained an odd-shaped bicycle part at a U.S. Customs and Border Protection warehouse. The facility inspects packages and mail arriving through LAX. Large quantities of counterfeit medications, drugs, cigars, beauty products and clothing are confiscated daily. Photos by Brad Graverson 5-21-13

item.title: L.A., Orange County Gasoline Prices Lowest on Labor Day Since 2010
item.description:
LOS ANGELES (CNS) - The average price of a gallon of self-serve regular gasoline in Los Angeles County rose three-tenths of a cent today to $3.864, the lowest for a Labor Day since 2010.

The average price set a Labor Day record of $4.173 in 2012, which analysts attributed to the Aug. 6, 2012, fire at the Chevron refinery in Richmond, which reduced its refining capacity and supplies.
item.dc:creator: By City News Service

media:content.media:description: (AP Photo/LM Otero, File)

item.title: Anti-al-Qaida leader escapes assassination in Iraq
item.description: BAGHDAD (AP) - A prominent leader of a militia opposed to al-Qaida escaped an assassination attempt Monday that killed six of his body guards and one civilian and wounded eight people, authorities said. Seven more people were killed and 15 wounded in separate violence in Baghdad and another Iraqi city as the country reels from waves of sectarian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Qassim Abdul-Zahra Associated Press

item.title: 10 injured in Temecula tour bus crash
item.description:
TEMECULA, Calif. (AP) - Ten people were injured in a crash of a tour bus that was headed from Los Angeles to an Indian casino in northern San Diego County, authorities said Monday.

A group of 18 people was aboard the bus when it careened off the road and crashed into some trees and boulders about 10:50 p.
item.dc:creator: By Associated Press

item.title: Obama seeks Syria support from former foe McCain
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama, seeking a congressional endorsement for U.S. military intervention in civil war-wracked Syria, is inviting two leading Capitol Hill foreign policy hawks to the White House in efforts to sell the idea to a nation deeply scarred by more than a decade of war.
item.dc:creator: Jim Kuhnenn Associated Press

media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by CBS News, Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., talks about the U.S. response to Syria on CBS's "Face the Nation" in Washington Sunday, Sept. 1, 2013. McCain said he and others on Capitol Hill would want to see a plan and a strategy, that will achieve some goals that the country needs achieved. (AP Photo/CBS News, Chris Usher)

A demonstrator holds a placard with a picture of U.S. President Barack Obama during a protest against possible U.S. forces' strike in Syria, in Cairo, Egypt, Sunday, Sept. 1, 2013. A top Syrian government official on Sunday dismissed the Obama administration as confused and hesitant, even as Secretary of State John Kerry said Washington has evidence of sarin gas use by Syria and that the case for a military attack is getting "stronger and stronger." (AP Photo/Lefteris Pitarakis)

item.title: Unlikely Salinger detective spent decade on trail
item.description:
LOS ANGELES (AP) - Shane Salerno's phone never stops ringing.

Known until now as a screenwriter for "Armageddon" and "Savages," working by day on a sequel to "Avatar," he has taken on a surprising and news-making identity: the latest, and, apparently, greatest seeker of clues about J.
item.dc:creator: Hillel Italie AP National Writer

media:content.media:description: This undated image provided by The Story Factory, shows J.D. Salinger working on "Catcher in the Rye" during World War II. Shane Salerno, a screenwriter, has taken on a surprising and news-making identity: the latest, and, apparently, greatest seeker of clues about J.D. Salinger.(AP Photo/The Story Factory, Paul Fitzgerald)

In this undated image provided by The Story Factory, "Catcher in the Rye" author, J.D. Salinger plays with his dog, Benny. Shane Salerno, a screenwriter, has taken on a surprising and news-making identity: the latest, and, apparently, greatest seeker of clues about J.D. Salinger. (AP Photo/The Story Factory, Paul Fitzgerald)

item.title: South Africa welcomes Mandela's return home
item.description:
JOHANNESBURG (AP) - South Africans on Monday welcomed Nelson Mandela's discharge from a hospital after nearly three months of treatment amid concerns that his health remains so poor that he still must receive intensive care at home.

An ambulance returned the 95-year-old leader of the anti-apartheid movement to his home in the leafy Johannesburg neighborhood of Houghton on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Christoper Torchia Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Grandsons Andile Mandela, left, walks with brother Mbuso, right, and unidentified man, outside their grandfather's, former South African President Nelson Mandela's house in Johannesburg, South Africa Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. South Africans on Monday welcomed Nelson Mandela's discharge from a hospital after nearly three months of treatment amid concerns that his health remains so poor that he still must receive intensive care at home. (AP Photo/Themba Hadebe)

A police officer holds flowers after collecting them from a well wisher, outside the former South African President Nelson Mandela's house in Johannesburg, South Africa Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. South Africans on Monday welcomed Nelson Mandela's discharge from a hospital after nearly three months of treatment amid concerns that his health remains so poor that he still must receive intensive care at home. (AP Photo/Themba Hadebe)

item.title: Egypt judges recommend dissolving the Brotherhood
item.description:
CAIRO (AP) - A panel of Egyptian judges recommended Monday the dissolution of the Muslim Brotherhood group, adding momentum to a push by authorities to ban the ousted Islamist president's main backers.

Since the military deposed Mohammed Morsi in a July 3 coup, it has steadily intensified a crackdown on the Brotherhood, Egypt's largest political organization.
item.dc:creator: Sarah El Deeb Associated Press

media:content.media:description: In this Wednesday, June 26, 2013 file photo released by the Egyptian Presidency, Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi delivers a speech in Cairo, Egypt. (AP Photo/Egyptian Presidency)

item.title: Russia doubts US proof of Syria poison gas use
item.description: DAMASCUS, Syria (AP) - Evidence of alleged chemical weapons use by the Syrian regime presented to Moscow by the U.S. and its allies is "absolutely unconvincing," Russia's foreign minister said Monday, as the Obama administration lobbied Congress to support a punitive military strike against Syria.
item.dc:creator: Albert Aji Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Russian members of pro-Kremlin parties take part in a picket against a possible US military action against Syria near the US Consulate in St.Petersburg, Russia, Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. The banner reads "Hands off Syria".(AP Photo/Dmitry Lovetsky)

item.title: Is Jerry Brown's obstinancy a big hurdle in prison battle: Dan Walters
item.description:
By Dan Walters

Darrell Steinberg, the state Senate's top leader, is offering Gov. Jerry Brown a way to salvage something positive from his otherwise losing fight over prisons.

But will Brown take it? Tom Hayden, the politician/journalist who protected Brown's left flank when he was paddling his political canoe to the right three-plus decades ago, points out in a Rolling Stone article about Brown that the governor tends to become very stubborn when he's wrong on an issue.

item.title: Senior Moments: The Dollar Tree
item.description:
So the lady from the Dollar Tree has been haunting me.

I met her when my husband and I decided to take what we call "a trip to nowhere" - just a drive to get away for the day, which that day, turned out to be Arvin.

Never heard of it? Neither had we. Roughly speaking, it is a little over a hundred miles north of Los Angeles and a little southeast of Bakersfield.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Bunin, LA Daily News

item.title: Does bad breath come with aging?
item.description:
Q I have an uncomfortable and somewhat personal question. My father-in-law is in his late 80s and has bad breath. It is difficult to sit next to him at dinners. I don't feel comfortable discussing this with him. Is bad breath a normal function of aging and is there some way to approach the topic delicately?

- L.

media:content.media:description: Smiling couple sitting in hammock

item.title: BEACH VOLLEYBALL: Notre Dame's Zana Muno captures Cal Cup 18-under title
item.description:
MANHATTAN BEACH >> Notre Dame junior Zana Muno won nine tournament titles last summer, but came up just short of the perfect 10 at the California Beach Volleyball Association Cal Cap Youth Championships.

Although Muno didn't approach that impressive total on the sand this summer, especially competing against older opponents in most tournaments, she arrived Sunday at the Cal Cup 18-under state championship looking to complete some unfinished business.
item.dc:creator: By Erik Boal erik.boal@dailynews.com @DNPrepSports on Twitter

item.title: San Fernando Valley, Hollywood families to get technology, job-training programs to break cycle of poverty
item.description:
In a gritty corner of the northeast San Fernando Valley, where poverty and violence have been a way of life for generations, tens of thousands of families are being offered the promise of a brighter future.

There are similar signs of hope in east Hollywood, where high unemployment and dropout rates have created desperate conditions for adults and children alike.
item.dc:creator: Barbara Jones, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: The nonprofit Youth Policy Institute has received a $30 million grant to create services to support families in Hollywood and the Pacoima-San Fernando neighborhoods. Here, cheerleaders at San Fernando Institute for Applied Media practice a routine August 27, 2013.(Andy Holzman/Los Angeles Daily News)

Youth Policy Institute Chief Operating Office Iris Zuniga looks on as a student at works on a computer project at San Fernando Institute for Applied Media August 27, 2013.(Andy Holzman/Los Angeles Daily News)

item.title: Friends, family show their love for burlesque queen Dixie Evans
item.description:
The story goes, honk three times and Dixie Evans, a red-lipped, curvy blonde, would greet visitors at the gate of the famed Exotic World Museum in the high desert of San Bernardino.

Now the late Evans will be keeping an ear out for the honks at the pearly gates where her fans believe the burlesque queen now rests.
item.dc:creator: Mariecar Mendoza, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Standing next to an earlier photo of herself, Dixie Evans, of Helendale, does her impersonation of Marilyn Monroe Tuesday, November 8, 2005, while giving a tour at the Exotic World Burlesque Museum and Striptease Hall of Fame in Helendale. Dixie Evans, 80, was known as "The Marilyn Monroe of Burlesque" and has become a sort of matriarch for the new burlesque dancers and the reemergence of Burlesque. Jennifer Cappuccio Maher/Staff Photographer

item.title: Angels complete sweep of Brewers
item.description:
Angels closer Ernesto Frieri threw pitch after pitch to Jonathan Lucroy with the bases loaded in the eighth inning Sunday, only to watch Lucroy keep fouling them off.

Finally, on his 12th delivery, Frieri got Lucroy to swing and miss, ending the long at-bat. Frieri then struck out rookie Khris Davis as well and pitched a scoreless ninth to help the Angels hold on for a 5-3 win over the Milwaukee Brewers and a three-game sweep of their interleague series.

item.title: 'Mermaid,' cooks cool with their jobs at the L.A. County Fair
item.description:
POMONA >> A mermaid inside a water tank and a griller outside in the sun would appear to have opposite experiences at the L.A. County Fair.

On Sunday, in the 90-degree heat that felt north of 100 degrees in the sun, Jerald Smith and Ernesto Ojeda, both of San Diego, flipped burgers or chicken in black shirts while wearing hats to stop the sweat coming down their foreheads.
item.dc:creator: Wes Woods, Inland Valley Daily Bulletin

media:content.media:description: Melissa the Mermaid astonishes crowds at the Beneath The Sea: An Underwater Adventure during the 91st Annual Los Angeles County Fair in Pomona August 31, 2013. When it comes to working in the heat, different jobs at the Fair bring different challenges. GABRIEL LUIS ACOSTA/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER.

item.title: Play it Forward: Best of this week's sporting events
item.description:
THIS WEEK'S BEST BET:

NFL WEEK 1:

Baltimore at Denver, 5:30 p.m. Thursday, Channel 4:

N.Y. Giants at Dallas, 5:30 p.m. Sunday, Channel 4:

Green Bay at San Francisco, 1:25 p.m., Channel 11:

Oakland at Indianapolis, 10 a.m. Channel 2:

We found out back in March that the NFL didn't get its way, and the defending Super Bowl champion Ravens wouldn't be opening the 2013 season at home, breaking a long-held tradition (going back to 2002).
item.dc:creator: Tom Hoffarth, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: UCLA offensive line earns promising reviews
item.description:
As the first round of camera flashes dimmed Saturday, Brett Hundley pointed up and closed with these words: "Shoutout to the O-line."

A year ago, a young patchworked UCLA line did little to keep Hundley from getting sacked 52 times - the highest total of any Pac-12 quarterback.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wang, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: The offensive line helped UCLA power to 647 yards in total offense vs. Nevada.

item.title: Kiffin: Still no QB starter for USC
item.description:
USC coach Lane Kiffin wants to minimize the Trojans' quarterback controversy but only maximized it Sunday when he selected a starter but refused to name him until Saturday's game against Washington State.

Kiffin said his goal is to keep outsiders from "tearing kids apart" by asking questions to the loser of the competition.
item.dc:creator: Scott Wolf, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: Dodgers now working toward World Series
item.description:
Ready for the Dodgers' glorified one-month spring training?

Early fall, style?

That's what it's come to, really.

With all due respect to Dodgers manager Don Mattingly, who respectfully declined to think too far down the road when the calendar flipped over from August to September on Sunday, but with the club continuing to tinker with the roster despite leading its division by 11 1/2 games, it's pretty obvious the objective is now setting things up correctly for a deep run in the postseason.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Bonsignore, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: NFL TEAM-BY-TEAM SCHEDULES
item.description:
AMERICAN CONFERENCE

Baltimore Ravens

Sep. 5 at Denver 5:30 p.m.

Sep. 15 Cleveland 10 a.m.

Sep. 22 Houston 10 a.m.

Sep. 29 at Buffalo 10 a.m.

Oct. 6 at Miami 10 a.m.

Oct. 13 Green Bay 10 a.m.

Oct. 20 at Pittsburgh 1:25 p.m.

Oct. 27 BYE

Nov.

item.title: Dodgers continue to add depth to roster
item.description:
The Dodgers clubhouse will be more crowded this month, not only with Saturday's acquisition of veteran Michael Young, but with the five September call-ups who were added to the team Sunday.

The Dodgers called up pitchers Stephen Fife and Peter Moylan, infielder/outfielder Scott Van Slyke, infielder Dee Gordon and catcher Drew Butera.
item.dc:creator: Dave Thorpe, Daily Breeze

item.title: Zack Greinke, Yasiel Puig deliver in Dodgers' win over Padres
item.description:
Zack Greinke went 5-0 with a 1.23 ERA in August. He doesn't look so bad in September, either.

Greinke was locked in a pitchers' duel with Tyson Ross for five innings. But then Ross was done, Yasiel Puig delivered a big blow, Greinke still had his legs, and the Dodgers recorded a 2-1 victory in front of a sell-out crowd of 52,168 on Sunday afternoon to sweep the San Diego Padres.
item.dc:creator: Dave Thorpe, Daily Breeze

media:content.media:description: Yasiel Puig watches his home run in the sixth inning that gave the Dodgers a 2-1 lead over the Padres at Dodger Stadium on Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Cal State Long Beach team hopes to take flight in Flugtag event
item.description:
LONG BEACH >> Those daring young men and women in their flying machines will be taking to the skies later this month as the Red Bull Flugtag competition returns to Long Beach.

Among the nearly 30 teams chosen to compete in Long Beach's contest, including some from as far away as Alaska, is a five-student group from Cal State Long Beach's Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers or SHPE.
item.dc:creator: Beatriz Valenzuela, Press-Telegram

media:content.media:description: Flight team members Ruben Cabral, left, and Jesus Enriquez with a mockup of the Phoenix, a fabled flying bird they will build to compete in the Red Bull Flutag competition. This team is from the CSULB Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers, and Day of the Dead is theme of their entry, thus the face paint. (Brad Graverson / Staff Photographer)

MaryCruz Zelaya will be the pilot of the Phoenix in the Red Bull Flutag event. This team is from the CSULB Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers. Team name is Viaje de los Muertos (Day of the Dead). (Brad Graverson / Staff Photographer)

item.title: Police warn against leaving windows open as hot weather continues
item.description:
More hot weather is predicted for Southern California in the coming week, prompting law enforcement officials to warn residents to be wary of burglars creeping through open windows.

Labor Day was expected to bring high temperatures in the mid-90s to the San Gabriel and San Fernando Valleys, with temperatures in the high-90s in the Inland Empire, Meteorologist Carol Smith of the National Weather Service's Oxnard office said.
item.dc:creator: Brian Day, San Gabriel Valley Tribune

item.title: Oh, baby! Yasiel may become a hit with soon-to-be parents
item.description:
Puig-mania that has swept Dodgers nation may lead some parents to name their children after the Cuban phenomenon, experts say.

Many credit Yasiel Puig, the 22-year-old outfielder who made his Major League debut in June, for igniting the last-place Dodgers to being the hottest team in baseball.
item.dc:creator: By Sarah Favot sarah.favot@sgvn.com @sarahfavot on Twitter

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Dodgers' Yasiel Puig looks on during practice for a baseball game against the San Diego Padres on Friday, Aug. 30, 2013, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: At Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti's Help Desk, no question is too small
item.description:
Debra McLaurin, 62, had a problem. The parking ticket she received in downtown Los Angeles was issued in error, McLaurin insisted. Seated before the new Mayor's Help Desk, the Palmdale resident waved photos that proved she was legally parked, she said.

McLaurin, who wore a white baseball cap with the phrase "Respect" written in gold cursive lettering, drove three hours from Palmdale to City Hall, she said.
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Sally Martinez takes a call at the help desk. The Mayor has launched a new help desk on the third floor of City Hall. (John McCoy / Staff Photographer)

item.title: New Van Nuys fire station proposal draws neighbors' ire
item.description:
The city's ambitious plans to replace the Valley's oldest fire station is running into opposition from residents of the Van Nuys neighborhood where the state-of-the-art facility is to be built.

Residents, many of whom said they are considering legal action if it is approved, complain the city failed to give adequate notice on the plans to replace Fire Station 39 with a new two-story facility at the intersection of Oxnard Street and Vesper Avenue.
item.dc:creator: Rick Orlov, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Fire Department station 39, across from Van Nuys City Hall, is the oldest fire station in the Valley. Thursday, August 29, 2013. (Michael Owen Baker /Staff Photographer)

item.title: Rebuilding ties to labor
item.description:
Even though he received more than $2 million from public and private employee unions, Mayor Eric Garcetti's initial weeks in office have been marked by cool relations with labor.

He has not met with Maria Elena Durazo, the executive secretary-treasurer of the County Federation of Labor, AFL-CIO, since his election, though Durazo said she has sent out feelers to Garcetti to try to arrange a meeting.
item.dc:creator: Rick Orlov, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: One dead, two injured after two cars collide in northeast Los Angeles
item.description:
One man died and two more were injured, including one critically, after a car ran a red light early Sunday and collided with another car at a northeast Los Angeles intersection, according to Los Angeles Police Department officials.

Alejandro Wong, 22, of Los Angeles was pronounced dead in the 6:45 a.
item.dc:creator: Brenda Gazzar, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: The state and challenges of L.A.'s labor movement
item.description:
Even with slight improvements in the economy, the labor movement in Los Angeles continues to face challenges in 2013, fighting to keep what it has and head off renewed efforts to scale back salaries and pensions.

At the same time, the L.A. labor movement is being singled out for its work in organizing new workers, immigration reform and other social issues that have helped it gain new power.
item.dc:creator: Rick Orlov, Los Angeles Daily News

item.title: Citing sarin use, US seeks Congress' OK for action
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Obama administration geared up for the biggest foreign policy vote since the Iraq war by arguing Sunday that new physical evidence shows the Syrian government used sarin gas in a deadly August attack. With its credibility on the line, the United States must respond, the country's top diplomat said.
item.dc:creator: BRADLEY KLAPPER Associated Press

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 30, 2013 file photo Secretary of State John Kerry makes a statement about Syria at the State Department in Washington. Kerry said in a series of interviews on news shows Sunday, Sept. 1, 2013, that the United States now has evidence of sarin gas use in Syria through samples of hair and blood provided to Washington by first responders in Damascus. He said Syrian President Bashar Assad "has now joined the list of Adolf Hitler and Saddam Hussein" in deploying chemical weapons against his population and echoed President Barack Obama in saying the world cannot stand by and watch Assad use chemical weapons. (AP Photo/Charles Dharapak)

Demonstrators hold a banner referring to U.S. President Barack Obama during a protest against possible U.S. forces' strike in Syria, in Cairo, Egypt, Sunday, Sept. 1, 2013. A top Syrian government official on Sunday dismissed the Obama administration as confused and hesitant, even as Secretary of State John Kerry said Washington has evidence of sarin gas use by Syria and that the case for a military attack is getting "stronger and stronger." (AP Photo/Lefteris Pitarakis)

item.title: Dixie Evans, godmother of burlesque, honored at Las Vegas tribute show
item.description:
LAS VEGAS >> Underneath all the tassels and behind the feather fans glows a sex kitten who owes her career to Dixie Evans.

More than 100 people hooted and hollered as 14 ladies took the stage at United We Shimmy, a one-night-only strip tease show on Saturday at The Plaza in downtown Las Vegas in honor of Dixie, the godmother of burlesque.
item.dc:creator: Mariecar Mendoza, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: Rosalita Nikita performs Saturday, August 31, 2013, at the United Vegas Shimmies! Dixie Evans Week benefit show at The Plaza Casino Showroom in Las Vegas. Jennifer Cappuccio Maher/Inland Valley Daily Bulletin

item.title: Egypt's Mohammed Morsi to be tried for inciting violence
item.description:
CAIRO (AP) - Egypt's top prosecutor referred Sunday ousted Islamist President Mohammed Morsi to trial on charges of inciting the killing of opponents protesting outside his palace while he was in office, the state news agency said.

The military ousted Morsi on July 3 after millions took to the street demanding he step down.
item.dc:creator: SARAH EL DEEB Associated Press

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Friday, July 13, 2012 file photo, Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi holds a joint news conference with Tunisian President Moncef Marzouki, unseen, at the presidential palace in Cairo, Egypt. Egypt's state news agency said Sunday, Sept. 1, 2013, the country's top prosecutor has referred ousted Islamist President Mohammed Morsi to trial on charges of inciting the killing of opponents protesting outside his palace while he was in office. (AP Photo/Maya Alleruzzo, File)

item.title: Man fatally struck by car while walking on Harbor 110 Freeway
item.description:
LOS ANGELES - A 52-year-old man was killed Sunday morning when he walked southbound in a northbound lane of the Harbor (110) Freeway and was struck by a car, the California Highway Patrol said.

The incident occurred at about 4:05 a.m. on the northbound Harbor Freeway just south of Martin Luther King Jr.
item.dc:creator: By City News Service

item.title: David Frost, known for Nixon interview, dies
item.description:
LONDON - David Frost may be best remembered for his post-Watergate interviews with former President Richard Nixon, but the veteran British broadcaster was equally at ease as a satirist, game show host and serious political journalist.

In a television career that spanned half a century across both sides of the Atlantic, Frost interviewed a long list of the world's most powerful and famous, including virtually every British prime minister and U.
item.dc:creator: By Sylvia Hui, The Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Broadcaster Sir David Frost poses for the photographers as he arrives for the European premiere of the 'Fire in Babylon' film at a central London cinema in this Monday, May 9, 2011 file photo. (AP Photo/Lefteris Pitarakis)
Former US President Richard M. Nixon, right, with broadcaster David Frost in California in this 1977 file photo. (AP Photo)

item.title: Mandela discharged from hospital, returns home
item.description:
JOHANNESBURG (AP) - Nelson Mandela went home in an ambulance on Sunday after nearly three months in a hospital that became the focus of a global outpouring of concern, but authorities said the health of the former South African president remained critical and sometimes unstable.

The return of the 95-year-old leader of the anti-apartheid movement to his home in an affluent neighborhood of Johannesburg allows his family to share time with him in a more intimate setting.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press

media:content.media:description: File - Former South African President Nelson Mandela at a news conference in Johannesburg, in this Wednesday, March, 5, 2008 file photo. Mandela has been discharged from hospital Sunday Sept. 1 2013, where he has been treated for months with a recurring lung infection. Mandela was released to his home in Johannesburg's Houghton suburb. (AP Photo/Denis Farrell, file)

item.title: NYC music fest canceled after 2 drug-linked deaths
item.description:
NEW YORK (AP) - A New York City dance music festival featuring high-profile acts including Avicii, David Guetta and Diplo has been canceled after the deaths of two attendees were apparently linked to drugs.

The city says it recommended Electric Zoo festival not continue Sunday after two people died and four others had to be hospitalized during the first two days of performances on Friday and Saturday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: John Kerry: US has evidence sarin gas was used in Syria
item.description:
WASHINGTON (AP) - Secretary of State John Kerry asserted Sunday that the United States now has evidence of sarin gas use in Syria and said "the case gets stronger by the day" for a military attack.

A day after President Barack Obama stepped back from his threat to launch an attack, Kerry said in a series of interviews on the Sunday news shows that the administration learned of the sarin use within the past 24 hours through samples of hair and blood provided to Washington by first responders in Damascus.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Hundley leads UCLA over Nevada
item.description:
PASADENA >> From the time Brett Hundley committed to play football at UCLA, he's been viewed as savior of the program.

The Arizona native lived up to those expectations last season by keying UCLA's run to the Pac-12 South title, and he showed Saturday he's far from finished.
item.dc:creator: Steve Ramirez, San Gabriel Valley Tribune

item.title: Man wanted in connection with 210 Freeway death arrested on murder charges
item.description:
The boyfriend of a woman who was killed after falling out of a car on the 210 Freeway was arrested on suspicion of murder late Saturday night.

Ricardo "Rick" Jimenez, 26, is being held at the Van Nuys jail in lieu of $1 million bail, police said, accused of murdering his 22-year-old girlfriend Maria Josefina "Josie" Jimenez.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Goff, Los Angeles Daily News

media:content.media:description: ‘Josie’ Jimenez
Ricardo Jimenez
